awd_titl_txt: Microdroplet On-tissue Chemical Reactions for Mass Spectrometric Imaging of the Untargeted Metabolome
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Young-Jin Lee and his group at Iowa State University are developing a new approach to the imaging and characterization of the surface of biological tissue, involving chemical reactions in surface microdroplets to improve the ability to detect metabolites (products of cellular processes) on the surface using the powerful analytical probe know as "mass spectrometry." This is the first systematic study of reaction acceleration in microdroplets for on-surface derivatization. Fundamental understanding of on-surface microdroplet reactions will lead to the effective analysis of small metabolites by mass spectrometry imaging that are otherwise impossible to detect. The potential impact spans across many scientific disciplines and analytical projects, including biomarker discovery, plant metabolomics, food safety, drug metabolism, and biodefense. A diverse group of students will be recruited to participate in the project through various channels including the American Chemical Society's Project SEED for economically disadvantaged high-school students and the McNair Program for first generation and underrepresented students.

The objective of this project is to understand on-surface microdroplet reactions, find out major driving forces by comparing neutral vs electrosprayed reagent droplets, and manipulate the reaction conditions to improve reaction efficiencies while minimizing ion suppression and cross-reactivity.  A selected set of reactions is being studied to achieve these goals for the derivatization of amines, carboxylic acids, ketones/aldehydes, and vicinal diols.  Furthermore, novel on-surface hydrogen deuterium exchange is being developed as a way to assist metabolite identification directly from the tissue surface. Most metabolomics studies are currently being performed without recognizing cell-specific or tissue-specific metabolism.  With the success of this research, mass spectrometry imaging will allow better understanding of metabolic biology in multicellular organisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most metabolomics studies are currently being performed without recognizing cell-specific or tissue-specific metabolism. Mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) is a technology that can study metabolism in single cell-resolution directly on tissues but limited by the low abundance and low ionization efficiency of some metabolites in a small sampling size. On-tissue chemical derivatization (OTCD) has become a tool of choice to overcome this limitation, but it has been used only for targeted analysis of a few selected metabolites. 

This project explored the potential of microdroplet OTCD to expand the capability of the mass spectrometry imaging for untargeted metabolomics in single cell resolution. Several important accomplishments are made toward this objective. First, in collaboration with Alexandrov team at European Molecular Biology Laboratory, on-tissue chemical derivatization strategy is implemented to a web-based metabolite annotation platform for MSI data, METASPACE (https://metaspace2020.eu), for streamlined untargeted metabolite annotations. This tool allows for anybody to upload their MSI data set and automatically annotate against metabolite database with OTCD. Now OTCD-MSI data set can be widely disseminated worldwide through this platform. Secondly, highly efficient gas phase in-source hydrogen-deuterium exchange (HDX) method is developed for matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI)-MSI using D2O vapor and deuterated matrix. This approach assists unknown metabolite identification by providing information about the number of exchangeable hydrogens in each metabolite. Thirdly, OTCD-based sample preparation method is developed to analyze volatile compounds with MALDI-MSI. It is demonstrated for MSI of short chain fatty acids in gut microbiome study. Also achieved include side-reaction studies of OTCD and the application of OTCD in amino acid imaging of maize roots.

The potential impact spans across many scientific disciplines and analytical projects, including biomarker discovery, plant metabolomics, food safety, drug metabolism, and biodefense. OTCD protocol is published to promote further dissemination of OTCD-MSI. Five graduate students had an opportunity to involve in this project and present their research outcome in national conferences. One undergraduate student in multi-cultural vision program and one high school student in ACS SEED project participated to this project and exposed to this state-of-the-art multidisciplinary STEM research.
